description:
Using developmental and systems frameworks and a family centered approach, the health and illness needs of children from birth through adolescence, and the related needs of their caregivers are addressed. The student is provided with a theory base, as well as opportunities for providing care to children with acute and chronic health problems, and their families. Using critical thinking, including the nursing process, strategies are developed for optimizing health; maintaining individuality; promoting optimal developmental, physiological, and psychological functioning; and, for enhancing strengths within the family unit. 

There are three primary foci for this course: taking care of sick children and families, child development, and professionalism.
name: NURSING OF CHILDREN: THEORY/CLINICAL

values.comments:
Using developmental and systems frameworks and a family centered approach, the health and illness needs of children from birth through adolescence, and the related needs of their caregivers are addressed. The student is provided with a theory base, as well as opportunities for providing care to children with acute and chronic health problems, and their families. Using critical thinking, including the nursing process, strategies are developed for optimizing health; maintaining individuality; promoting optimal developmental, physiological, and psychological functioning; and, for enhancing strengths within the family unit. There are three primary foci for this course: taking care of sick children and families, child development, and professionalism.

In general, students found the course to be highly organized and “well-delivered.” Some students commented that this class made them “seriously think of going into pediatric nursing.” Most lectures were stimulating and provided up-to-date information on pediatric health conditions. A few students found some of the lectures to be “overloaded with information” and had content that was beyond the scope of the students.

The course was co-taught by Professors Connolly, Hickerson, and Curley. Students found Professor Hickerson to be “the best part of the course.” Many students commented on Professor Hickerson’s accessibility and dedication to making the lecture and clinical portion a “valuable learning experience.” One student stated that Professor Hickerson “did not rely on slides and had engaging lectures.”

Students generally felt the course was rather difficult but put together well. Students appreciated that there were few assignments to complete in addition to the two exams and weekly databases. Some students commented that the two in-class exams were inconsistent in their levels of complexity. This course is designed specifically for nursing majors and would not be appropriate for students outside of the nursing program. The prerequisites for the class include NURS 104, 106, 131, 132.

Using developmental and systems frameworks and a family centered approach, the health and illness needs of children from birth through adolescence, and the related needs of their caregivers are addressed. The student is provided with a theory base, as well as opportunities for providing care to children with acute and chronic health problems, and their families. Using critical thinking, including the nursing process, strategies are developed for optimizing health; maintaining individuality; promoting optimal developmental, physiological, and psychological functioning; and, for enhancing strengths within the family unit. There are three primary foci for this course: taking care of sick children and families, child development, and professionalism.

In general, students found the course to be highly organized and “well-delivered.” Some students commented that this class made them “seriously think of going into pediatric nursing.” Most lectures were stimulating and provided up-to-date information on pediatric health conditions. A few students found some of the lectures to be “overloaded with information” and had content that was beyond the scope of the students.

The course was co-taught by Professors Connolly, Hickerson, and Curley. Students found Professor Curley to be intelligent and able to provide “excellent information” in her lectures. Most students felt Professor Curley was approachable, had a “strong interest in the students” and coordinated the course nicely.

Students generally felt the course was rather difficult but put together well. Students appreciated that there were few assignments to complete in addition to the two exams and weekly databases. Some students commented that the two in-class exams were inconsistent in their levels of complexity. This course is designed specifically for nursing majors and would not be appropriate for students outside of the nursing program. The prerequisites for the class include NURS 104, 106, 131, 132.

Using developmental and systems frameworks and a family centered approach, the health and illness needs of children from birth through adolescence, and the related needs of their caregivers are addressed. The student is provided with a theory base, as well as opportunities for providing care to children with acute and chronic health problems, and their families. Using critical thinking, including the nursing process, strategies are developed for optimizing health; maintaining individuality; promoting optimal developmental, physiological, and psychological functioning; and, for enhancing strengths within the family unit. There are three primary foci for this course: taking care of sick children and families, child development, and professionalism.

In general, students found the course to be highly organized and “well-delivered.” Some students commented that this class made them “seriously think of going into pediatric nursing.” Most lectures were stimulating and provided up-to-date information on pediatric health conditions. A few students found some of the lectures to be “overloaded with information” and had content that was beyond the scope of the students.

The course was co-taught by Professors Connolly, Hickerson, and Curley. Students found Professor Connolly to be intelligent, “receptive to students” and eager to help. However, many students felt Professor Connolly’s lectures were “difficult to follow”, not focused, and presented poorly.

Students generally felt the course was rather difficult but put together well. Students appreciated that there were few assignments to complete in addition to the two exams and weekly databases. Some students commented that the two in-class exams were inconsistent in their levels of complexity. This course is designed specifically for nursing majors and would not be appropriate for students outside of the nursing program. The prerequisites for the class include NURS 104, 106, 131, 132.
